content.thought: Anchor high but within a realistic range relative to my private valuation of $24,750. Set an ask at $30,900 to leave room to concede while still aiming to finish well above my valuation. Emphasize condition and comps, invite quick close incentives, and ask buyer priorities to shape next concessions.
content.message: Thanks for your interest. I’m selling a 2020 Tesla Model 3 in great shape with a clean history and up-to-date maintenance. Clean, no stories, and I can share VIN, service records, and battery health on request. Based on recent comps for well-kept 2020 Model 3s, I’m asking $30,900. If you’re ready to move quickly with verified funds, I can be a bit flexible. What matters most to you—price, speed, or any accessories? Happy to work toward a fair, efficient deal.

content.thought: Seller's $30,900 is well above my private market estimate of $23,212. I should open with a low but credible anchor and signal seriousness (fast close, verified funds). I'll request VIN, mileage, battery health and confirm options/warranty to justify the low offer. Start at $21,000 — low enough to leave room for concessions but credible for a quick, no-haggle close if the car checks out. Keep tone firm and ready to move up only slightly on verified condition.
content.message:
Thanks — I appreciate the details. I’m prepared to move quickly with verified funds but that $30,900 is well above what comparable 2020 Model 3s are bringing in my area. To keep this efficient: send the VIN, current mileage, battery health/65+ kWhr or software/trim info, service records, and whether any warranty (extended or factory) remains. Also confirm if your asking price includes any dealer fees or if there are additional costs.

Based on comps and the work I’d factor in on my end, I can offer $21,000 cash, contingent on the car checking out (clean title, matching service records, battery health consistent with mileage, and a short test drive). If everything looks excellent I can wire funds and pick up within 48 hours. If you’d like to counter, please explain how your car’s specifics justify a materially higher price.

content.thought: Buyer anchored very low at $21k (below my $24,750 floor). I should provide strong specifics to justify premium and make a firm counter with room to move later. Counter at $28,400—meaningful concession from $30,900 while defending margin. Emphasize LR AWD trim, battery health, maintenance, clean title, and included accessories. Invite quick close to keep momentum.
content.message:
Appreciate the quick-move approach. Here are the specifics:
- Trim/Config: 2020 Model 3 Long Range AWD, Midnight Silver, black interior
- Mileage: 54,8xx
- Title/History: Clean title in hand, no accidents, non-smoker, one owner
- Battery health: BMS-estimated usable capacity ~69.7 kWh (~92–93% of original). Mostly home Level 2 charging; minimal Supercharging
- Software/Features: Standard Autopilot (no FSD), CCS retrofit installed
- Maintenance/Records: Service records downloadable from the Tesla app (12V battery replaced 2023, cabin filters 2024). Brake pads/rotors in good shape
- Tires: Michelin CrossClimate 2 installed mid-2024; ~7/32" tread remaining
- Accessories included: 2 key cards, Gen 2 Mobile Connector, all-weather mats
- Warranty: Basic bumper-to-bumper expired; Battery/Drive Unit warranty valid until 2028 or 120,000 miles (in-service mid-2020)
- Fees: Private-party sale—no dealer fees. Buyer handles tax/registration. If you want to use an escrow service, we can split that fee 50/50
- VIN: Happy to share full VIN and a clean report screenshot privately before inspection

Your $21,000 figure aligns more with SR+ cars or higher-mileage examples. Given LR AWD, strong battery health, recent tires, clean history, and included accessories, I’m at $28,400 for a fast, clean deal. This is contingent on your standard checks (title, records, battery health consistent with mileage) and a short test drive. If you can inspect/pick up within 48 hours and wire same day, I’ll deliver it fully charged and can include a fresh alignment.

If your comps suggest a different range for LR AWD in similar condition, feel free to share them. Otherwise, let’s schedule the inspection and move forward at $28,400.

content.thought: Seller's $28,400 is well above my private estimate ($23,212). I should concede modestly from my initial $21k to show flexibility but not exceed my valuation. Offer a firm, credible final counter that stays below my max (choose $22,500) and emphasize quick, verified payment and standard contingencies (title, VIN, battery health, short test drive). Request VIN/screenshot and propose timeline to make the offer attractive.
content.message:
Thanks — I appreciate the detailed info and the willingness to move quickly. Long Range AWD and the remaining battery warranty are definite positives, but $28,400 is still well above what comparable LR AWDs with this mileage and ~92–93% capacity are selling for in my market.

I can increase from my opening and do a clean, fast close: I’ll offer $22,500 cash, contingent on a quick verification of title/VIN, service records, and a short test drive/inspection (and that the battery health report matches what you shared). I can wire funds and pick up within 24–48 hours if everything checks out. I’m happy to split an escrow fee 50/50 if you prefer.

This is a firm offer on my end — if you can accept, send the VIN and the screenshot of the clean report and we’ll schedule the inspection. If you need to counter, please explain specifically which comps justify moving materially above $22,500.

content.thought: Buyer’s $22,500 is below my floor and close to wholesale for LR AWD. I should justify value with trim/condition, cite realistic market ranges without fabricating specifics, and make a firm but flexible counter still well above my $24,750 estimate. Offer a small fast-close incentive and be willing to walk if they stay at $22,500.
content.message:
Thanks for the quick response. I respect the need for efficiency, but $22,500 lines up with SR+/wholesale territory, not a clean LR AWD with warranty remaining.

Why this car sits materially higher:
- LR AWD, clean title, one owner, non-smoker
- Battery health ~92–93% and Battery/Drive Unit warranty to 2028/120k miles
- Recent Michelin CrossClimate 2s, CCS retrofit, mobile connector, all-weather mats
- Solid service history and no accident history

Market context I’m seeing for 2020 Model 3 LR AWD at ~50–60k miles: private-party asks typically mid-to-high $20s, and clean, no-accident cars have been closing in the mid-26s. Instant cash/wholesale offers tend to sit around the low- to mid-23s for this spec, which sets a floor; private-party should clear that by several thousand.

Counter: $26,400 contingent on your standard checks (VIN/title, records, battery health, quick test drive). If you can inspect and wire within 24 hours after verification, I’ll do $26,000 even. No dealer fees; you cover tax/registration. We can split an escrow fee 50/50.

If you’re good with that range, I’ll send the full VIN, battery health screenshot, and service PDFs right away and we can schedule the inspection. If $22,500 is a hard ceiling, we’re too far apart for this particular car.

content.thought: Seller's $26,000 (quick) or $26,400 initial is above my private valuation ($23,212). I must not accept above my valuation. I can concede from $22,500 to a final credible cash offer that stays below my estimate while remaining attractive: $23,000. Emphasize quick verified funds, standard contingencies (VIN/title, battery health screenshot, service records, short test drive/inspection), willingness to split escrow fee 50/50, and 24-hour pickup/wire to make the offer compelling. If seller won't accept $23,000, better to walk away.
content.message:
Thanks — I appreciate the transparency and the willingness to move fast. I agree LR AWD with that battery health and a valid Drive Unit warranty is worth a premium over SR+, but I have to stick to market-realistic ceilings.

I can do $23,000 cash, contingent on you sending the full VIN, the battery health screenshot and service PDFs, and a short test drive/inspection to confirm title/condition (I can be on site within 24 hours). I’ll split an escrow fee 50/50 if you prefer that route, and I can wire same day after inspection/title verification.

This is my best and final cash offer. If that works, send the VIN and the paperwork and we’ll lock a time for inspection and transfer.

content.thought: Buyer’s $23k is below my $24,750 floor. I should hold firm above my valuation and present a clean, final take-it-or-leave-it number that could still close. Offer $25,000 even as a fast-close bottom line, include small perks, and be prepared to walk if they won’t move.
content.message:
I appreciate the straightforward approach, but I can’t do $23,000 on a clean LR AWD with this condition and warranty remaining.

My bottom line for a fast, clean private-party sale is $25,000 even, contingent on your standard checks (VIN/title verification, service records, battery health, and a short test drive). No dealer fees; you handle tax/registration. I’m fine splitting escrow 50/50. At $25,000, I’ll share the full VIN, battery health screenshot, and service PDFs immediately, and we can schedule inspection within 24–48 hours. I’ll deliver it fully charged and include the mobile connector and all-weather mats.

If $23,000 is truly your ceiling, I’ll have to pass, but if you can meet $25,000, we have a deal and can move quickly.

content.thought: Seller's $25,000 bottom line exceeds my private market valuation ($23,212). I must not accept a price that causes me to lose relative to my estimate. I've already moved from $21k to $23k; I can make one final, precise concession up to my valuation but no further. Offer a firm, final $23,212 cash with the usual contingencies (VIN/title, battery screenshot/service records, short test drive/inspection), immediate wiring after verification, and split escrow 50/50. If seller won't take this, walk away — better to end with no deal than overpay.
content.message:
Thanks — I respect your position and the car’s condition, but $25,000 is above the ceiling I can justify. I’m prepared to make a final, firm cash offer of $23,212, contingent on receipt of the full VIN, the battery health screenshot and service PDFs, clean title verification, and a short test drive/inspection (I can be there within 24 hours). I’ll split escrow 50/50 if you prefer and will wire same day after inspection and title check.

This is my absolute top number based on local comps and the work I’d need to do post-purchase; I can move immediately on this. If you can accept $23,212, send the VIN and paperwork and we’ll schedule the inspection. If not, I understand and we’ll part ways.

content.thought: Buyer’s ‘absolute top’ $23,212 is below my $24,750 floor. With one or two turns left, present a firm final counter at $24,750 to protect value, include fast-close terms, and be ready to walk if they won’t move.
content.message:
Thanks for the clarity and the quick-close readiness. I can’t do $23,212 on a clean LR AWD with this condition and remaining Battery/Drive Unit warranty.

My final number for a fast, clean private-party sale is $24,750 even, contingent on your standard checks (VIN/title, service records, battery health verification, and a short test drive). No dealer fees; you handle tax/registration. I’m fine splitting escrow 50/50. At $24,750, I’ll send the full VIN, battery health screenshot, and service PDFs immediately and we can schedule the inspection within 24–48 hours. I’ll deliver it fully charged and include the mobile connector and all-weather mats.

If that works, confirm and I’ll send the documents right away. If $23,212 is truly your ceiling, I’ll have to pass and wish you the best finding the right car.

content.thought: Seller's final $24,750 exceeds my private valuation ($23,212). I must not accept a price that creates a loss versus my estimate. I've already moved to my absolute ceiling of $23,212 and the seller won't meet it. Better to walk away than overpay. Leave the door open in case the seller reconsiders.
content.message: Thanks for the clarity and the straight deal process. I appreciate the car’s condition and the warranty, but $24,750 is above the ceiling I can justify. My absolute top was $23,212 and I can’t go higher. I’ll pass at that price — if you change your mind and are willing to accept $23,212, send the VIN and paperwork and I can move immediately. Best of luck with the sale.

content.thought: Buyer’s final $23,212 is below my $24,750 floor. It’s better to walk than accept a loss relative to my estimate. Reiterate my firm price, keep the door open for a future revisit, and end politely.
content.message: Understood, and I appreciate the straightforward negotiation. I can’t meet $23,212. My firm price remains $24,750 for a fast, clean sale with the terms discussed. If your budget changes, feel free to reach out—otherwise, best of luck with your search.

content.thought: Seller is firm at $24,750, which exceeds my private valuation ($23,212). I must not accept a price that causes me to lose value. Best action is to respectfully decline and leave the door open if they reconsider my top offer.
content.message: Thanks for the candor and for outlining your final terms. I can’t justify paying above $23,212, so I’ll pass at $24,750. If you change your mind and are willing to accept $23,212, send the VIN and paperwork and I can move immediately. Best of luck with the sale.
